metadata.title: Synthesis of Cu/Zn/Al/Mg catalysts on methanol production by different precipitation methods

Research Paper Synthesis of Cu/Zn/Al/Mg catalysts on methanol production by different precipitation methods Fan Zhang a b Yulong Zhang a ⁎ Yuan Liu a Khaled A.M. Gasem c Jingyun Chen a Fukuo Chiang a Yonggang Wang b Maohong Fan c ⁎ a National Institute of Clean-and-Low-Carbon Energy, Beijing 102211, PR China National Institute of Clean-and-Low-Carbon Energy Beijing 102211 PR China b School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, Beijing 100083, PR China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering China University of Mining and Technology Beijing 100083 PR China c Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Wyoming, Laramie, WY 82071, USA Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering University of Wyoming Laramie WY 82071 USA ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The Mg containing catalyst prepared by fractional precipitation exhibits higher CO conversion than the co-precipitation catalyst after heat treatment (5MPa, and GHSV=10000h−1; 80% H2, 13% CO, 2% CO2 and 5% N2). Mg-containing Cu/Zn/Al industrial catalysts for methanol synthesis have been widely used in coal industry. The objective of this work is to investigate the influence of precipitation methods and Mg addition on the performance of Cu/Zn/Al/Mg methanol synthesis catalyst. A series of Cu0.6Zn0.3Al0.1Mgx catalysts (x: 0-0.04) were prepared by co-precipitation and fractional-precipitation methods, respectively. The catalyst samples were characterized with various methods including XRD, TG-MS, XPS, SEM, TEM/EDS, N2 physisorption and N2O chemisorption. Results show that Mg improved the BET surface area and Cu dispersion of the catalysts prepared by co-precipitation, while the corresponding catalytic activity decreased with the addition of Mg. Fractional precipitation could facilitate the Cu substitution by Zn in the subcarbonate precursor, and eliminate the negative effect caused by Mg addition. Though the formation of Mg-Al hydrotalcite was unfavorable, the catalysts obtained with fractional precipitation demonstrated better catalytic performances than those prepared by co-precipitation method. It is suggested that fractional-precipitation method is more suitable than co-precipitation for preparing the Cu/Zn/Al/Mg methanol synthesis catalyst. Keywords Fractional precipitation Subcarbonates Hydrotalcite-like compounds High-temperature carbonates Mg 1 Introduction Coal utilization technologies have attracted extensive attention from researchers worldwide because of the abundant coal reserves [1–3]. Since CO2 emissions from direct coal combustion pose a significant problem in coal utilization [4], many researchers have focused on coal gasification and its downstream synthetic industries [5,6]. Methanol provides a pathway to transform synthesis gas from coal gasification into valuable hydrocarbons, such as olefins and gasoline [7,8]. Further, it offers access to a variety of important industrial products, such as formaldehyde, and dimethyl ether [9]. As such, methanol plays an increasingly important role in the coal industry. Methanol is usually produced from synthesis gas mixtures (CO/CO2/H2) at typical reaction conditions of 230–280°C and 5–10MPa over Cu-based catalysts. In this industrially dominant low-pressure process, the Cu-based catalyst is typically composed of Cu, Zn, and Al, with Cu/Zn used as active component, and Al is used as structural promoter [10]. For further improvement, a small fraction of other metals were added, which have provided positive effect on the catalyst performance [11–13]. Mg-containing Cu/Zn/Al industrial catalysts for methanol synthesis have been developed in 1990s [14,15], and they are currently widely applied in the industrial units, especially in China. Mg2+ is an interesting element because its charge is the same as Cu2+ and its ionic radius is close to that of Cu2+ [16]. Meshkini et al., [17] investigated the effect of metal oxides on the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst from co-precipitation by using a 1/16 full-factorial experiment design, and they found that MgO had a negative effect on the catalytic activity but a positive effect on the stability of the catalyst. However, an explanation for the findings was not given in their study. Słoczynski et al., [12] studied the Mg effect in Cu/Zn/Zr catalyst for methanol synthesis from CO2, and suggested that Mg promoted the catalyst activity by improving the adsorptive properties. Zander et al., [16] found that the methanol production rate from synthesis gas by Cu/MgO/ZnO catalyst was higher than that by Cu/ZnO catalyst, and they ascribed it to the higher Cu dispersion caused by Mg addition. Schuman et al., [18] studied the Mg doped Cu/ZnO catalyst for methanol synthesis from syngas by conductivity measurements, and reported a detrimental effect of Mg2+ in the methanol synthesis reaction. These discussions suggested that the interaction between Mg and Cu/ZnO structure caused the effect of Mg on the catalyst activity. Traditional co-precipitation was often employed for preparing the methanol synthesis catalyst [19]. In co-precipitation, the metal ions were added together into the mother liquor, and Mg2+ has opportunity to contact with Cu2+ and Zn2+. Another possibility should be considered is the combination of Mg2+ with Al3+, which can be realized by fractional precipitation. It is reported that fractional precipitation was used to prepare efficient methanol synthesis catalysts, in which Al3+ is precipitated independently of Cu2+ and Zn2+ [20,21]. The method can facilitate the connection between Mg2+ and Al3+. The effect of the Mg-Al connection on the catalyst should be considered. In this work, co-precipitation and fractional-precipitation methods were employed to synthesize the Cu/Zn/Al/Mg catalysts, with their performances compared. The effect of Mg addition on the catalysts produced by both methods was investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts A solution with various Cu2+:Zn2+:Al3+:Mg2+ ion ratios was prepared by dissolving the mixture of Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O, Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O, Al(NO3)3∙9H2O and Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O in demineralized water. The concentration of the metal ions in solution is 1.0mol/L with 1.5 of the Al3+ molar quantity present. Also, a solution with 1.0mol/L CO3 2− was used as a precipitant; it was prepared by dissolving the sodium carbonate in deionized water. The solution with metal ions and the solution with CO3 2− were preheated to specified temperature by water bath before they were used. All reagents used in this work were of analytical quality/grade provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Beijing Co., Ltd. In co-precipitation process, the aqueous solution with metal ions and the aqueous solution with CO3 2− were concurrently dripped into a heated balloon flask containing 100ml of deionized water under vigorous stirring. The metal nitrate solution was pumped continuously at a constant flow rate, while the CO3 2− solution was added with controlled flow rate to maintain the pH of the suspensions between 7.0 and 8.0. The precipitation was finished when approximate 200ml of metal ion solution was added in 30min. In the fractional-precipitation process, the solution with Al3+ and Mg2+ was pumped into the flask in the initial step, and then the solution with Cu2+ and Zn2+ was added into the same flask. Here too, the pH was controlled by the flow rate of CO3 2− solution in both steps. The resulting precipitate was aged for 2h, and then was filtered and washed to get rid of Na+. The conductivity of the washed water was examined to make sure little ion remains in the precipitate. Subsequently, the precipitate was dried at 110°C for 12h and calcined at 350°C in a muffle furnace under air flow for 4h (2°C/min). The precipitate samples before calcination were collected for characterization. The catalyst names and their design composition are listed in Table 1 . 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were performed on powdered catalyst precursors and calcined samples in a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffraction system using the Cu Kα line (1.5406Å) obtained at 40kV/40mA, with 2θ ranging from 10° to 90° with 0.020° steps and a dwell time of 0.05s/step. The crystallite size of Cu in reduced catalyst was estimated from the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the basic Cu XRD peaks [2θ=43.19°, (111)] using the Scherrer equation, as shown below. (E1) S i z e ( n m ) = k λ β cos θ , where k is the shape factor which is 0.89 for spherical particles, λ is the X-ray wavelength (1.5406Å), and β is the FWHM in radians. The instrumental error was calibrated by the standard silicon provided by Japan pure chemical CO., LTD. The XRD pattern of the standard silicon is shown in the supporting information (Fig. S1). Thermogravimetric mass spectrometry (TG-MS) analyses were carried out using a Netzsch STA 449F3 Jupiter thermogravimetric differential thermal analyzer linked to a MS403C Aeolos mass spectrometer. Samples were heated up to 750°C with a linear-temperature program at a heating rate of 10°C/min in continuous flow of synthetic air (30ml/min). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on Thermo Scientific K-alpha spectrometer system equipped with monochromatic Al Kα (1486.6kV) X-ray source, a hemispherical energy analyzer and multi-stage samples cabin. All binding energies were calibrated using the C1s peak at 284.6eV as the reference. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were obtained by JSM-5900LV type (Japan) series instrument with a Schottky field emission gun at an accelerating voltage of 20kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken with JEOL 2011 Electron Microscope operating at 200kV. Simultaneous energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was used to analyze the element distributions in the samples. Specific surface area and pore volume of the samples were measured at −196°C, using Micromeritics Tristar 3000 equipment. Each sample was de-gassed in the Micromeritics system at 300°C for 3h prior to adsorption [22]. The dispersion of Cu (DCu ) and the exposed Cu surface area (SCu ) were determined by dissociative N2O adsorption and carried out on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 auto adsorption apparatus. The sample (100mg) was dried at 300°C for 1h, and then it was reduced in a 10% H2/Ar mixture (30ml/min) for 1h at 300°C. The amount of hydrogen consumption was denoted as X in this step. Then, the reduced samples were cooled to 65°C and isothermally purged with Ar for 30min, after that the sample was exposed to 10%N2O/Ar (50ml/min) for 1h to ensure complete oxidation of the metallic copper. The sample was then flushed with Ar and cooled to 50°C. Finally, a flow of 10% H2/Ar mixture was passed over the catalyst at 300°C. The surface Cu+ ions were reduced and the amount of H2 consumption was denoted as Y. The dispersion (Dcu ) of Cu and the exposed Cu surface area (SCu ) of the catalyst were calculated by the equations [23,24]: D C u = 2 Y X × 100 % S C u = ( 2 n H 2 × N ) / ( 1.4 × 10 19 × W ) ( m 2 g − 1 ) , where nH2 is molar number of consumed H2 during the second reduction; N is Avogadro’s constant (6.02×1023 atoms mol−1); 1.4×1019 is the number of copper atoms per square meter; and W is the weight of the reduced catalyst. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The evaluation experiment was performed in a continuous-flow, constant-pressure fixed-bed reactor. Fig. 1 shows the catalyst evaluation apparatus used in this work. A catalyst (100mg, 40–60mesh) diluted with 1g quartz sand (40∼60mesh) was placed in a stainless steel tube reactor heated by a multi-sectional tubular furnace. The temperatures of the reactor and the tubular furnace were monitored by thermocouples. Prior to reaction, the catalyst was reduced in gas mixture (5%H2, 95%N2) at 230°C under atmospheric pressure. The initial activity was measured under the conditions of 230°C, 5MPa, and GHSV=10000h−1 with feed gas composed of 80% H2, 13% CO, 2% CO2 and 5% N2 (Air Liquide). Before entering the reactor, the feed gas was purified by a gas purification tank to remove residual sulfur and chlorine. In thermo stability measurement, the catalyst sample was held at 320°C for 24h, and then was tested at 230°C for another 24h. A heating tape was used to keep the products at desired temperatures at the outlet of the reactor. Then, methanol and water in the products were separated through a water-cooled condenser and collected into a vial. The cleaned gas products were quantitatively analyzed with an online gas chromatograph, and then the extra gas products were vented into the fume hood. The CO conversion of each test was calculated by an internal normalization method. The methanol yield and selectivity were calculated based on the carbon balance. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of the prepared materials A fraction of precipitates before and after calcination were collected for XRD analyses, and the results were shown in Fig. 2 and Table 2 . Both hydrotalcite-like compounds (HTlc) and subcarbonates were detected in the samples using the co-precipitation method. The peaks at 11.750°, 23.579°, and 34.617° were attributed to the existence of (Cu,Zn)6Al2(OH)16CO3∙4H2O [25]. The formation of subcarbonates was described by the reaction model proposed by Li et al., [26,27]: (R1) Cu2+ +2OH− →Cu(OH)2 (s) (R2) 3Cu(OH)2 (s)+Cu2+ +2NO3 − →Cu (NO3)2∙Cu (OH)2 (s) (R3) Cu (NO3)2∙Cu (OH)2 (s)+CO3 2− →Cu2(OH)2CO3 (s)+2NO3 − Reaction 3 is the crucial reaction to the catalyst performance, where the precipitate color changing from light blue (hydroxynitrate) to malachite green (subcarbonates) [28,29]. The formation reaction of rosasite was added to the reaction model [26], either as: (R4) Cu(OH)2 (s)+Zn2+ +CO3 2− →(Cu, Zn)2(OH)2CO3 (s), or through the reaction of isomorphous substitution during aging time [25]: (R5) Cu2(OH)2CO3 (s)+Zn2+ →(Cu, Zn)2(OH)2CO3 (s)+Cu2+. In fractional precipitation, HTlc could not be observed in sample MF01 since Al3+ precipitation was independent of Cu2+ and Zn2+. Aluminum hydroxide formed by Al3+ precipitation was supposed to be scattered evenly in the precursor, thus could not be observed in the XRD patterns. The peaks of aurichalcite (distinct at 13.028° [30]) were observed in the XRD pattern of MF01, which may be formed by the following reaction [31]: (R6) Zn5(CO3)2(OH)6 (s)+Cu2+ →(Cu,Zn)5(CO3)2(OH)6 (s)+Zn2+ It is possible that malachite, rosasite and aurichalcite exist in the precursors concurrently [28,29], and they are classified into subcarbonates in this work. In the preparation of sample MF03, the Mg-Al hydrotalcite formation occurred during the precipitation. The excess Al3+ was precipitated to form aluminum hydroxide. It is reported that the substitution of Cu2+ with Zn2+ in malachite crystal structure result in the shift of 20 1 ¯ and 21 1 ¯ reflections to higher angles in the XRD patterns [32]. As shown in Fig. 2b, it was found that MC01 shows the lowest Cu-Zn substitution based on this study. The explanation is that part of Zn participated in the formation of HTlc, resulting in the low ratio of Cu/Zn in the subcarbonates. Mg addition promoted the Cu substitution in MC03. The possible reason is that Mg2+, alike Zn2+, replaced Cu2+ in the malachite lattice and participated in the HTlc formation. Both behaviors enhanced the Cu substitution in the subcarbonates. Fractional precipitation prevented the consumption of Zn2+ in HTlc, thus the obtained catalysts had higher Cu substitution degree than the co-precipitation catalysts. Fig. 2c and d shows the XRD patterns of the calcined and reduced catalyst samples. The structures of HTlc/HT and subcarbonates were destroyed at the calcined temperature and only the diffraction peaks for CuO were observed. The crystallite sizes of Cu derived from CuO reduction were provided in Fig. 2d. The Cu particle size of MC03 is smaller than other catalysts, indicating the positive effect of Mg on the Cu dispersion in co-precipitation. It is supposed that Cu-Zn substitution in subcarbonates was beneficial to the formation of small Cu particles [21,33]. However, the Cu particle sizes in this work were inconsistent with the Cu-Zn substitution result. Some other factors should also have an effect on the Cu particle size, such as the Mg addition and the different precipitation methods. ZnO was also observed in sample MF01 and MF03. The explanation is that the formation of HTlc, which could promote the Zn dispersion, was inhibited in fractional precipitation. As shown in Fig. 3 , the textural properties of the catalyst precursors were investigated by TG/DTG analyses. Four peaks were observed in the DTG profiles of the co-precipitation precursors. The weight loss at ∼150°C was ascribed to the dehydration of HTlc or HT [34]; the weight loss between 200°C and 400°C was attributed to the removal of H2O and CO2 from HTlc or HT structure [35,36], the decomposition of malachite, and the initial decomposition of rosasite and/or aurichalcite [37]. The peak at ∼500°C belonged to the decomposition of HT-CO3 originated from initial decomposition of rosasite and/or aurichalcite [37,38]. The last peak at around 590°C was assigned to the decomposition of HT-CO3 formed during the decomposition of HTlc or HT structure[34,39]. The peak at 360°C in the profile of MC01 was supposed to be caused by malachite decomposition. With the addition of Mg, the peak disappeared in the profiles of co-precipitation catalysts. For fractional-precipitation samples, the peaks at ∼310°C and ∼490°C belonged to the decomposition of subcarbonates. In sample MF03, the peaks at ∼150°C and ∼570°C should represent the decomposition of Mg-Al hydrotalcites. The TG-MS result shown in Fig. 4 proved the analyses. H2O effusion contributed to the formation of peaks at ∼150°C and ∼300°C, and CO2 effusion was responsible for the formation of peaks at ∼300°C, ∼500°C and ∼600°C. The TG results show that fractional precipitation inhibited the HTlc formation, which is corresponding to the XRD results. MC01 exhibited the lowest CO2 effusion at ∼500°C and a distinct peak at ∼360°C. It suggested that a considerable part of subcarbonates existed as malachite phase, which decomposed in one step before 400°C [38]. This is in agreement with the low Cu substitution of MC01 according to the XRD results. With Mg addition, the peak at ∼360°C disappeared and the CO2 effusion at ∼500°C was enhanced, which indicated the positive effect of Mg on the Cu substitution in the subcarbonates. The HT-CO3 decomposed at ∼500°C indicated the existence of rosasite and aurichalcite in the catalyst precursors [37,38,40]. CuO derived from these binary subcarbonates had a good contact with ZnO in the calcined catalyst, which plays a key role in the catalyst activity [19]. This may be the reason that the productivity-enhancing properties of the HT-CO3 were observed by researchers [27]. The calcined Cu/Zn/Al/Mg samples were also analyzed by XPS, with the relative surface contents presented in Table 3 . The original XPS spectra and the element compositions of the catalysts determined by Inductively-coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry are listed in the supporting information for reference (Fig. S2 and Table S1). The surface compositions of the catalysts roughly correspond to the designing composition listed in Table 1. As obtained by fractional precipitation, the surface Cu/Zn ratio of the catalysts was lower than the designing ratio. It was attributed to the Zn aggregation on the catalyst surface [34,41]. Besides the carbon contamination (284.6eV and 286.2eV), carbon from HT-CO3 (289.3eV) in the calcined samples was observed in the XPS results and was examined in Fig. 5 . The surface relative CO3 2− contents were listed in Table 3. It seems that there was a weak trend pointing to a higher relative surface CO3 2− content for the co-precipitation catalyst with higher Mg content. The HT-CO3 from HTlc was determined by Al amount in the co-precipitation catalyst, which kept relative constant in the catalyst preparation. Therefore, the increasing HT-CO3 should belong to the augment of binary subcarbonates, such as rosasite or aurichalcite, which is beneficial to the Cu dispersion of the catalyst [27]. This is in agreement with the Cu substitution results shown in Fig. 2b. An increase of CO3 2− contents in the fractional-precipitation catalysts was also observed and the reason was ascribed to the increasing amount of Mg-Al hydrotalcite, according to the XRD and TG-MS results. Fig. 6 shows the SEM images (∼1μm scale bar) of the calcined catalyst particles prepared by co-precipitation and fractional precipitation. Fiber phase, plate phase and irregular aggregates were observed in the catalyst samples. The fibers were attributed to the subcarbonate phase, and the plates belonged to the HTlc or HT phases [37,39]. The irregular aggregates may come from the independent precipitation of Al3+ in the fractional precipitation. Both fibers and plates could be observed in all the co-precipitation samples. Obtained by fractional precipitation, plate phases could hardly be found in sample MF01; when Mg content increased, some materials with platelet-like morphology were observed in the samples, which were attributed to the formation of Mg-Al hydrotalcites. For further examining the fiber phase, STEM/EDS analyses were conducted on sample MC03 and MF03, with the EDS results shown in Fig. 7 . The STEM images of the measured part were listed in the supporting information (Fig. S3). Compared with MF03, The fiber phase in MC03 was not clear, which may be caused by the disordered agglomeration of the small fibers. Fiber phase was usually considered as the mixture of CuO and/or ZnO derived from subcarbonates [32]. The EDS results show that sample MF03 demonstrates low Cu:Zn ratio than sample MC03, which implies the high Cu substitution by Zn in the subacarbonates of MF03. The results also indicate that sample MC03 possesses higher contents of Al and Mg than MF03 in the measured part, which may be caused by the different precipitation methods. Another possible reason is that part of Cu was substituted by Mg2+ in the subcarbonates, and thus leading to the increase of Mg content in the subcarbonates. The BET results of the calcined samples were summarized in Table 4 . The specific surface area (SBET) of co-precipitation samples slightly increased with the addition of Mg. Pore structures formed by the well dispersed metal oxides from subcarbonates was beneficial to the BET surface area [16]. In fractional precipitation, the amount of aluminum hydroxide was reduced by the formation of Mg-Al hydrotalcites, leading to the decrease of SBET [21]. Table 4 also shows the Cu dispersion results determined by N2O chemisorption. The Cu dispersion of MC01 was lower than that of MF01. The reason was ascribed to the formation of HTlc [42,43]. With the addition of Mg, Cu dispersion increased in co-precipitation catalysts while decreased in fractional-precipitation catalysts. The variation is in good agreement with the BET results. In co-precipitation, Mg addition promoted the formation of binary subcarbonates according to the XRD, TG and XPS result, which was beneficial to the Cu dispersion [27]. In fractional precipitation, Cu dispersion slightly decreased with Mg addition. The sizes of Cu grains determined by N2O chemisorption are ∼1.5 times larger when compared to the sizes of Cu grains assessed from the XRD results. The possible reason is that a slight agglomeration of Cu grains leads to the formation of larger grains composed of the agglomerated Cu crystallites [12]. Another possible reason is that part of the Cu grains cannot be detected by N2O chemisorption because of the substitution in subcarbonates [23] or the embedment in HTl structure [43], leading to the larger Cu particles estimated by N2O chemisorption based on spherical particle model. Nevertheless, the XRD results on Cu grains are qualitatively in agreement with the results obtained by the N2O chemisorption. 3.2 Catalyst performance and discussions In methanol synthesis, the reactions are the CO hydrogenation and CO2 hydrogenation, as shown below: (R7) CO+2H2 ⇌CH3OH △H298 =−90.55kJ/mol (R8) CO2 +3H2 ⇌CH3OH+H2O △H298 =−49.43kJ/mol, This is in addition to the water gas shift (WGS) reaction: (R9) CO+H2O⇌CO2 +H2 △H298 =−41.12kJ/mol The reaction mechanism, such as the carbon source of methanol and the intermediate species during hydrogenation, is still under debate [44–46]. In this work, it is assumed that CO2 is the direct carbon source in the methanol synthesis reaction at CO/CO2/H2 atmosphere with Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 used as the catalyst [44]. CO hydrogenation is blocked in the described conditions due to the relatively weak binding of carbon atoms by Zn [44] or the strong site-blocking effect of formate on CO hydrogenation [21]. Therefore, the main reactions are CO2 hydrogenation (R8) and the WGS reaction (R9). WGS reaction cleans the catalyst surface from adsorbed water, and simultaneously provides new CO2 for methanol production. In this case, CO2 plays an intermediate role in the reaction and CO conversion is considered to be an appropriate catalytic activity indicator, with the results shown in Fig. 8 . The temperature change during the tests was included in the figures. the reaction temperature initially remained at 230°C for 24h (stage I), and then it rose to 320°C and was held for 24h again (stage II); after that, it dropped to 230°C and remained as such for another 24h (stage III). The average CO conversion, methanol selectivity and methanol yield of the catalysts at each stage were presented in Table 5 . In stage I, fractional-precipitation catalysts generally had higher CH3OH yields than their counterparts from co-precipitation. The CO conversion of fractional-precipitation catalysts was relatively more stable than those of co-precipitation catalysts with Mg addition, as shown in Fig. 8. At 320°C, co-precipitation catalysts had higher CO conversion but lower CH3OH selectivity, leading to lower CH3OH yields compared to the fractional-precipitation catalysts. It can be seen from R8 and R9 that the methanol synthesis is an exothermic process. There should be a balance between dynamic equilibrium and thermodynamic equilibrium to enable a high methanol-formation rate at 230–280°C. Further increasing temperature is unfavorable to the balance, and leading to the low CO conversion at 320°C. After heat treatment, the CH3OH selectivity of all catalysts was very close, but the CO conversion of co-precipitation catalysts with Mg slumped compared to it in stage I. On the contrary, the CO conversion for fractional-precipitation catalysts kept at relatively high levels after heat treating. Li et al. evaluated the Cu0.6Zn0.3Al0.1 catalyst prepared by co-precipitation at 20bar, 225°C and a space velocity of 7000h−1, with H2/CO/CO2 =66.7/30.2/3.1 (vol.%), and the obtained methanol yield is ∼0.5 ggcat −1 h−1 [26], which is lower than the methanol yield obtained by the co-precipitation catalyst in this work. Bahmani et al. studied the Cu0.6Zn0.3Al0.1 catalyst prepared with aluminum hydrous oxide sol [21]. The reaction conditions are 230°C, 50bar and a space velocity of 17250h−1, with synthesis gas feedstock ratio H2/CO/CO2 =80:12:8 (mol%). The obtained methanol yield is ∼1.6ggcat −1 h−1, which is close to the methanol yields of the fractional-precipitation catalyst in this work. It should be mentioned that their evaluation conditions are slightly different. In Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalyst, ZnO mainly has two functions: 1) As nanoparticles it acts as a physical spacer between the Cu particles, stabilizing the porous microstructure; and 2) as a thin layer at the surface of the Cu particles it is an essential ingredient for the active site [16]. Based on this study, low substitution of Cu by Zn in the subcarbonate lattice is detrimental to the catalyst activity and stability, as shown in Fig. 9 . This may be the reason why MC01 had lower catalyst activity and thermal stability than MF01. MC01 prepared by co-precipitation exhibited low Cu-Zn substitution according to the characterization results, since part of Zn2+ was consumed in the HTlc structure. Fractional precipitation suppressed the formation of HTlc, and thus promoting Cu substitution by Zn in the malachite structure lattice. With the addition of Mg, the CO conversion of co-precipitation catalysts demonstrated a sharp decline after heat treating, indicating detrimental effect of Mg on the catalyst activity. The possible reasons are: (1) part of Cu in the malachite lattice was replaced by Mg, which inhibited the contact of Zn and Cu; (2) Mg addition promoted the formation of MgO-ZnO solid solution, which had negative effect on the strong metal-support interaction, as reported in Schumann et al.’s study [18]. The supposed structure models of sample MC03 and MF03 are shown in Fig. 10 . Upon calcination, the metal oxides derived from rosasite and/or aurichalcite segregated because of their different crystal structures and limited solubilities, forming a very fine interdispersion [26]. Although Mg addition promoted the Cu dispersion of MC03, the detrimental effect caused by Mg indicates that the contact of Mg with CuO-ZnO structure should be avoided. In sample MF03, It is possible that part of Mg was adjacent to the CuO-ZnO phase derived from subcarbonates. However, the Mg species from Mg-Al hydrotalcite should exist as MgO-Al2O3 phase, and it is difficult for Mg to contact closely with CuO-ZnO structure, since they were derived from different precursors. Therefore, the negative effect of Mg on the catalyst activity was not observed in the fractional-precipitation catalysts. It is found that CO conversion of fractional-precipitation catalysts was decreased with Mg addition, which was corresponding to the SBET and Cu dispersion results listed in Table 4. The reason was ascribed to the formation of Mg-Al hydrotalcite, which facilitated the aggregation of Al3+ and led to the decrease of well dispersed Al species. With Mg2+ content unchanged, the addition of more Al3+ during catalyst preparation could be beneficial to the increase of well dispersed Al species and may improve the performance of the Mg-containing catalyst by fraction precipitation. The work will be done in the future. Nevertheless, as fractional precipitation promoted the Cu-Zn substitution in subcarbonates and inhibited the unfavorable effect of Mg on the activity, the obtained catalysts performed better catalytic performance compared to their counterparts prepared by co-precipitation, especially after heat treating. 4 Conclusions The Cu/Zn/Al/Mg catalysts used for methanol synthesis were prepared by using co-precipitation and fractional-precipitation procedures. In co-precipitation, the specific surface area and Cu dispersion of the catalysts was improved with the addition of Mg, since it promoted the formation of binary subcarboantes. Small Cu grains were formed with the addition of Mg. With increasing Mg contents, the CO conversion of the co-precipitation catalysts was instable, and was easy to diminish through heat treating. The negative effect caused by Mg could be inhibited through fractional-precipitation method. By isolating Mg2+ and Al3+ from the Cu2+ and Zn2+, fractional precipitation could inhibit the formation of hydrotalcite-like compounds, and avoid the interference of Mg to the Cu/ZnO active component. The obtained catalysts demonstrated better catalytic activity and thermal stability than those prepared by co-precipitation approach. The method can be further improved by increasing the ratio of Al3+ in the catalyst preparation. Compared with co-precipitation, fractional-precipitation method is more suitable for preparing the Cu/Zn/Al/Mg methanol synthesis catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Mg-containing Cu/Zn/Al industrial catalysts for methanol synthesis have been widely used in coal industry. The objective of this work is to investigate the influence of precipitation methods and Mg addition on the performance of Cu/Zn/Al/Mg methanol synthesis catalyst. A series of Cu0.6Zn0.3Al0.1Mgx catalysts (x: 0-0.04) were prepared by co-precipitation and fractional-precipitation methods, respectively. The catalyst samples were characterized with various methods including XRD, TG-MS, XPS, SEM, TEM/EDS, N2 physisorption and N2O chemisorption. Results show that Mg improved the BET surface area and Cu dispersion of the catalysts prepared by co-precipitation, while the corresponding catalytic activity decreased with the addition of Mg. Fractional precipitation could facilitate the Cu substitution by Zn in the subcarbonate precursor, and eliminate the negative effect caused by Mg addition. Though the formation of Mg-Al hydrotalcite was unfavorable, the catalysts obtained with fractional precipitation demonstrated better catalytic performances than those prepared by co-precipitation method. It is suggested that fractional-precipitation method is more suitable than co-precipitation for preparing the Cu/Zn/Al/Mg methanol synthesis catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of Cu/Zn/Al/Mg catalysts on methanol production by different precipitation methods
